note.p: Andrew Monroe Hardin was a businessman and public official in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born in 1819 in Kentucky, Hardin moved to Mississippi as a young man. He partnered with M. D. Haynes in a grocery and dry good store in Yazoo City in the early 1850s, and his business dealings helped him become a prominent resident in the state. Hardin was appointed the superintendent of Mississippiâ€™s state penitentiary in the late 1850s and served in that role into the early 1860s. Following the Civil War, he returned to his business and retail interests, until becoming involved in the National Grange of the Order of Patrons of Husbandry, or more often known simply as the Grange, in the early 1870s. The organization emphasized agricultural development within communities. Hardin became a state agent for the Grange and moved to St. Louis, Missouri, around 1873. He remained there for several years, operating A. M. Hardin & Company, which specialized in agricultural equipment.

Hardin moved to Tennessee in the 1880s and passed away on May 2, 1891. He was married twice, first to Martha Wilson with whom he had at least one child. He later married Frances Burrus Edmunds. Hardin is buried in Elmwood Cemetery in Memphis, Tennessee.

(The Yazoo Democrat, Yazoo City, MS, January 21, 1852; The Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, August 18, 1858, and December 11, 1861; The Mississippi Press, Pascagoula, MS, July 10, 1875; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, November 13, 1873, and June 14, 1876; The Clarion, Jackson, MS, August 2, 1882; 1880 U.S. Census for District 388, Roll 734, Page 34a, St. Louis, Missouri; FindaGrave)

div.p: Perhaps it would be well for me to preface my letter by stating who I am. as you are a stranger to me & as I am to you.
I am the unfortunate individual that plead guilty to larceny, at the call term of the circuit county of Marion County in January 1861.
Overwhelm as I was at that time by shame and grief, I still remember your kind offer to defend me, with recollection of gratitude.
Although I am not guilty of the charge to the extent, that our would suppose from the course that I took, I was, yet I frankly admit I commited an error, one for which I am humbly ashame.

The circumstances of the case I will briefly give you, I had been boarding at Mr John MCollums for several days. previous to going to his house I had been dissipating for several months, nay I may say as many years. I lost my Trunk and Watch, I did not know where I had left them. but supposed I had left them in the hands of the person ^who^ I came in the neighborhood of Augusta with. While at Mr. MCollums I dreamed nothing, constantly was in one of those strange phenomona of mind that is only kown to those who feel it.
I asked Mr. M Callum to loan me a horse to ride to Augusta in Perry County (in which county he lives) to look after my Trunk and Watch, he done so

I started on my journey. I got in Company with a parcel of fellows who had Whisky, and I got drunk as usual, lay out in the woods all night, when I woke up next morning I was completely lost. the sky was overcast I could not see the sun, nor tell what time in the day it was, no road to guide me, after some meditation I determined on a course and started. I traveled the greater part of the day before I came to any habitation at all if you have ever been in that part of the Country you will not be surprise at this.

at length I came to a house, there were no persons at it except some small children, from whom I could get no information whatever, I continued my journey till dark overtook me, soon after I came to house within a few miles of Columbia in Marion County. I was sick from the debauch ^of the^ day before and knowing well the effects that would be produced if I did not get spirits of some kind I determined to push on to Columbia, a few miles further, ^I^ done [?] so, stoped at the Hotel, sent out and got a bottle of Brandy, and went to a room and went to bed. I was arrested in that condition, commited to jail The circumstances attending the trial you know.
It may seem strange to you, that I would pursue the course I did, under such a state of facts.
But if you were fully acquainted with the facts of my dissipation and ^the^ length to which I carried it, it would much tend to palliate my course
I had so often been disappointed in my efforts to reform, and so overwhelm with shame and dishonor, that I was indifferent even to life itself.

I verily believe, that had the penalty been death my course would have been the same. I thought that my life, and future reformation dependent upon that event, I am firmly of the opinion that if this misfortune had not befallen me, I would now be in the number of the dead. But from the kind treatment of the ^officers^ this institution (to whom I shall ever feel grateful) I have been completely and^I trust^ permanently reformed. By the kind suggestions of one the officers, I have been induced to address you this letter, with the view of soliciting your aid in my behalf, Although I have nothing at present to compensate you for your trouble, yet I hope that you will not refuse to aid me on that account, give me the assistance I need, and trust to my honor as a man, and ^you^ shall not have cause to regret it. Was it not for the unhappy condition of our Country I should not have pre-sumed to ask you to trust me

but I feel a glowing attachment to the Sunny land of my nativity I churish all her institutions with warmeth and ardor ^of^ a true patriot. I am convinced that a conflict, the most bloody and terific is about to be inaugurated, one in which Mississi-ppi, especially will need the services of every man in whose arm there is sufficient strength to wield a sword or lift a musket, I humbly and respectfully ask to be permitted to take part in the same, and share equally with our brave and gallant brothers now upon the tented field, the perils dangers and hardship of a soldiers life.

From the depths of my prison home, from the silence and solitude of my dark cold cell, my petitions are humbly offered to the God of battles that success may attend our cause, that the glorious banner of the conferate states, bathed in the blood of martyred heroes, may still float in the splendours of its triumphs, over our now beleagured and down trodden South.

I have already spun out this letter to an in [criditable?] length and will close by again imploring your aid. for my behavior and conduct have I respectfully refer you to Maj. Hardin, and the other officers of the place, let me hear from you soon

I am Your unfortunate sert
Charles Campbell
